title: Isaiah Chapter 47 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 47 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 47 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 47.

questions.question: Who is called the 'virgin daughter of Babylon' in Isaiah 47:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Virgin daughter of Babylon
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:1 addresses 'O virgin daughter of Babylon,' indicating the identity of the subject.

questions.question: What task is the daughter of Babylon instructed to do in Isaiah 47:2?
options: Take the millstones and grind meal
questions.correctAnswer: Take the millstones and grind meal
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:2 instructs her to 'Take the millstones, and grind meal,' showing a humbling task.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 47:3, what will be uncovered and seen?
questions.correctAnswer: Thy nakedness and shame
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:3 states, 'Thy nakedness shall be uncovered, yea, thy shame shall be seen.'

questions.question: Who is described as 'our redeemer' and 'the Holy One of Israel' in Isaiah 47:4?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD of hosts
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:4 says, 'As for our redeemer, the LORD of hosts is his name, the Holy One of Israel.'

questions.question: What is the daughter of the Chaldeans told to do in Isaiah 47:5?
options: Sit silent and get thee into darkness
questions.correctAnswer: Sit silent and get thee into darkness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:5 commands her to 'Sit thou silent, and get thee into darkness.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 47:6 says that God gave His people into the hand of the daughter of the Chaldeans.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:6 states, 'I have polluted mine inheritance, and given them into thine hand.'

questions.question: What did the daughter of Babylon say about her future in Isaiah 47:7?
options: I shall be a lady forever
questions.correctAnswer: I shall be a lady forever
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:7 quotes her saying, 'I shall be a lady for ever.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Isaiah 47:8: 'Therefore hear now this, thou that art given to ______, that dwellest carelessly.'
questions.correctAnswer: pleasures
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:8 says, 'thou that art given to pleasures, that dwellest carelessly.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 47:9, what two things shall come upon the daughter of Babylon in one day?
questions.correctAnswer: Loss of children and widowhood
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:9 says, 'these two things shall come to thee... the loss of children, and widowhood.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 47:10 says the daughter of Babylon trusted in her wickedness and said, 'None seeth me.'
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:10 states, 'thou hast trusted in thy wickedness: thou hast said, None seeth me.'

questions.question: What will come upon the daughter of Babylon suddenly according to Isaiah 47:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Desolation
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:11 says, 'and desolation shall come upon thee suddenly.'

questions.question: What is the daughter of Babylon challenged to stand with in Isaiah 47:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Her enchantments and sorceries
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:12 says, 'Stand now with thine enchantments, and with the multitude of thy sorceries.'

questions.question: Who are asked to save the daughter of Babylon in Isaiah 47:13?
questions.correctAnswer: Astrologers, stargazers, and monthly prognosticators
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:13 calls for 'the astrologers, the stargazers, the monthly prognosticators' to save her.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 47:14 says the fire will burn the astrologers and they will be able to warm themselves.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:14 says the fire will burn them and they 'shall not deliver themselves' nor be able to warm themselves.

questions.question: What will happen to the merchants who labored with the daughter of Babylon according to Isaiah 47:15?
options: They shall wander every one to his quarter
questions.correctAnswer: They shall wander every one to his quarter
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:15 states, 'they shall wander every one to his quarter; none shall save thee.'

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 47 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 47 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with pride and self-reliance. Based on Isaiah 47, what biblical truth would you share about trusting in God?
options: Trusting in your own wisdom leads to downfall
Self-reliance is the path to true strength
Pride is a sign of spiritual maturity
Humility is unnecessary if you are strong
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting in your own wisdom leads to downfall
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:10 warns that trusting in wickedness and relying on one's own wisdom perverts a person, leading to destruction. Verses 8-11 highlight the folly of pride and self-reliance without God.

questions.question: What practical lesson about humility and contentment can we learn from the fate of the daughter of Babylon in Isaiah 47?
options: Prideful boasting leads to sudden downfall
Humility is only for the weak
questions.correctAnswer: Prideful boasting leads to sudden downfall
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:7-9 shows how the daughter of Babylon did not consider the end of her pride and was suddenly humbled. This teaches us the importance of humility and remembering our dependence on God.

questions.question: If a believer is feeling overwhelmed by spiritual battles, how might Isaiah 47:12-13 encourage them regarding prayer and reliance on God rather than empty rituals?
options: Human efforts and rituals cannot save us; trust God alone
Magic and sorcery are effective in spiritual warfare
Astrology can predict and avoid trials
Prayer is less important than rituals
questions.correctAnswer: Human efforts and rituals cannot save us; trust God alone
questions.explanation: Verses 12-13 show the futility of relying on enchantments and astrologers. This teaches believers to depend wholly on God’s power through prayer and faith, not empty human means.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 47, how should believers respond to trials and temptations to maintain perseverance?
options: Stand firm in faith and trust God’s justice
Ignore the trial and pretend it doesn't exist
Give in to temptation to avoid pain
questions.correctAnswer: Stand firm in faith and trust God’s justice
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:11 reminds us that evil will come suddenly, but the chapter’s context teaches trust in God as Redeemer (verse 4) and the futility of relying on human power (verses 12-15).

questions.question: What biblical virtue is emphasized in Isaiah 47:4 when it speaks of the LORD of hosts being the Holy One of Israel?
options: Faith and trust in God as Redeemer
questions.correctAnswer: Faith and trust in God as Redeemer
questions.explanation: Verse 4 explicitly identifies God as Redeemer and Holy One, encouraging believers to place their faith and trust in Him rather than human strength or false security.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by loss and hardship. Based on Isaiah 47:9, what truth about God's justice and the consequences of sin can you share?
options: Sin and sorcery bring swift and perfect consequences
God overlooks sin in this life
Loss and hardship are unrelated to behavior
questions.correctAnswer: Sin and sorcery bring swift and perfect consequences
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:9 teaches that loss and widowhood come suddenly as consequences of sorceries and enchantments, illustrating God’s just judgment on sin and the importance of repentance.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 47:6-7 illustrate the importance of remembering God's discipline and not ignoring the consequences of sin?
options: Consequences of sin are temporary and harmless
Punishment is always deserved by others
questions.correctAnswer: Ignoring discipline leads to destruction
questions.explanation: Verses 6-7 reveal how Babylon ignored God's judgment and proudly assumed eternal power, forgetting the consequences. This teaches believers to heed God’s discipline as loving correction.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 47 teaches that trusting in worldly wisdom and secret knowledge brings true security and peace.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:10-11 clearly states that trusting in wickedness, wisdom, and knowledge apart from God leads to perversion and sudden destruction, not security.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 47, those who rely on merchants or worldly alliances for help will ultimately be saved.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 15 shows that merchants and those with whom Babylon labored will wander away, offering no salvation, emphasizing reliance only on God is true security.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 47:5 says, "Sit thou silent, and get thee into _______, O daughter of the Chaldeans."
questions.correctAnswer: darkness
questions.explanation: The verse commands the daughter of the Chaldeans to sit in silence and enter darkness, symbolizing judgment and loss of power, teaching humility and submission to God's will.

questions.question: Based on Isaiah 47:1-3, how does God view the pride and self-exaltation of the daughter of Babylon?
options: She will be humbled and exposed in shame
She will reign forever with honor
questions.correctAnswer: She will be humbled and exposed in shame
questions.explanation: Verses 1-3 describe how Babylon will be brought low, her nakedness and shame revealed as God takes vengeance, showing that pride leads to humiliation.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 47:14 teach us about relying on human counsel and false wisdom in times of trouble?
options: Human counsel will fail like stubble in fire
Human wisdom is the best defense
False wisdom brings protection from harm
Counselors can always save from troubles
questions.correctAnswer: Human counsel will fail like stubble in fire
questions.explanation: Verse 14 compares false advisors to stubble burned by fire, unable to save themselves or others, teaching reliance on God is the only true refuge.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 47:8-9 warn believers about the danger of living carelessly and indulging in worldly pleasures?
options: Careless pleasure leads to sudden loss and sorrow
questions.correctAnswer: Careless pleasure leads to sudden loss and sorrow
questions.explanation: Verses 8-9 warn that those living carelessly and indulging in pleasures will face sudden loss and widowhood, highlighting the need for vigilance and godly living.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 47:15, what happens to those who rely on their merchants and worldly allies for help in times of judgment?
options: They will wander away and no one will save them
They will be protected by their allies
Merchants will provide safety and refuge
Worldly allies will strengthen their position
questions.correctAnswer: They will wander away and no one will save them
questions.explanation: Verse 15 describes how merchants and associates will abandon them, emphasizing the futility of trusting in worldly help rather than God.

questions.question: What lesson about prayer and spiritual discipline can be drawn from Isaiah 47:12-13's depiction of sorceries and enchantments?
options: True spiritual power comes from God, not occult practices
Sorcery is a valid spiritual discipline
Prayer is unnecessary if you have knowledge
questions.correctAnswer: True spiritual power comes from God, not occult practices
questions.explanation: The passage condemns reliance on sorcery and enchantments, teaching believers to seek God through prayer and obedience instead of false spiritual disciplines.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 47 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 47.

questions.question: In Isaiah 47:1, the 'virgin daughter of Babylon' is instructed to come down and sit in the dust. What does this imagery most likely signify in the context of ancient Near Eastern prophetic literature?
options: A symbol of humbling and judgment against Babylon
An invitation to celebrate Babylon's greatness
A call for Babylon to build a new throne
A metaphor for Babylon's military conquest
questions.correctAnswer: A symbol of humbling and judgment against Babylon
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:1 uses the imagery of sitting in the dust and losing the throne as a symbol of humiliation and judgment upon Babylon, consistent with prophetic denouncements of proud cities.

questions.question: What is the significance of the command in Isaiah 47:2 to 'take the millstones, and grind meal' in relation to Babylon's predicted fate?
options: It symbolizes forced labor and humiliation
It indicates a time of abundance and prosperity
It is a metaphor for Babylon's military preparations
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes forced labor and humiliation
questions.explanation: Grinding meal on millstones was a menial task typically assigned to slaves or captives, symbolizing Babylon’s fall into a state of servitude and disgrace as seen in Isaiah 47:2.

questions.question: Isaiah 47:3 states, 'Thy nakedness shall be uncovered, yea, thy shame shall be seen.' Which literary device is primarily employed here?
options: Simile comparing Babylon to a naked woman
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor for disgrace and exposure
questions.explanation: The phrase uses nakedness metaphorically to represent Babylon’s shame and loss of protection, a common prophetic device to indicate humiliation as in Isaiah 47:3.

questions.question: Who is identified as the redeemer in Isaiah 47:4, and what is the significance of this title in the Old Testament context?
options: The LORD of hosts, emphasizing His sovereign power over nations
The prophet Isaiah, as an intercessor
The angel Michael, as protector of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD of hosts, emphasizing His sovereign power over nations
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:4 names the LORD of hosts as the redeemer, highlighting God's supreme authority and role as Israel’s protector and judge over nations, a central theme in Isaiah.

questions.question: In Isaiah 47:5, the daughter of the Chaldeans is told, 'Sit thou silent, and get thee into darkness.' What does this directive symbolize in prophetic judgment?
options: The silencing and downfall of Babylon’s power
A command to build a new temple
A metaphor for Babylon’s military expansion
questions.correctAnswer: The silencing and downfall of Babylon’s power
questions.explanation: The instruction to sit silent and enter darkness signifies the cessation of Babylon’s dominance and the onset of judgment and obscurity as per Isaiah 47:5.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 47:6, why did God give His people into the hand of Babylon?
options: Because He was angry and polluted His inheritance
To reward Babylon for its faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: Because He was angry and polluted His inheritance
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:6 states that God’s wrath against His people led to their being handed over to Babylon, reflecting divine judgment for Israel’s disobedience.

questions.question: What is the irony behind Babylon’s claim in Isaiah 47:7, 'I shall be a lady for ever'?
options: Babylon’s pride blinds it to its imminent downfall
Babylon is actually destined to become a queen
Babylon plans to destroy other nations
Babylon is confident in its religious rituals
questions.correctAnswer: Babylon’s pride blinds it to its imminent downfall
questions.explanation: The verse highlights Babylon’s arrogance and failure to consider the consequences of its actions, foreshadowing its destruction.

questions.question: Isaiah 47:8 describes Babylon as 'given to pleasures' and 'dwelling carelessly.' How does this characterization relate to the theme of judgment in the chapter?
options: It underscores Babylon’s moral decay leading to divine punishment
It calls for Babylon to enjoy life before exile
questions.correctAnswer: It underscores Babylon’s moral decay leading to divine punishment
questions.explanation: Babylon’s indulgence and negligence in Isaiah 47:8 set the stage for its downfall, linking moral failure to inevitable judgment.

questions.question: In Isaiah 47:9, what two calamities are said to come upon Babylon 'in one day'?
questions.correctAnswer: Loss of children and widowhood
questions.explanation: These two calamities symbolize the complete desolation and loss of Babylon’s power and progeny as punishment for its sorceries and enchantments.

questions.question: Isaiah 47:10 discusses Babylon’s trust in wickedness and the belief that 'None seeth me.' What Hebrew concept does this challenge?
options: The power of idols to save
questions.correctAnswer: The omniscience of God
questions.explanation: This verse challenges Babylon’s false sense of security by asserting that God sees all, countering their belief in hidden wickedness.

questions.question: What is the nature of the 'evil' and 'mischief' described in Isaiah 47:11 that will come upon Babylon?
questions.correctAnswer: Sudden and unpreventable desolation
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:11 depicts the judgment as swift and unavoidable, emphasizing the certainty of Babylon’s destruction.

questions.question: Isaiah 47:12-13 challenges Babylon to rely on its enchantments and astrologers. How does the response in verse 14 illustrate the futility of such reliance?
options: Their counsel will be consumed like stubble in fire
They will lead Babylon to victory
They will bring riches and honor
questions.correctAnswer: Their counsel will be consumed like stubble in fire
questions.explanation: Verse 14 uses the imagery of fire consuming stubble to demonstrate that Babylon’s magical arts and astrologers cannot save it from divine judgment.

questions.question: Isaiah 47:15 mentions merchants who 'shall wander every one to his quarter; none shall save thee.' What does this indicate about Babylon’s economic and political fate?
options: The collapse of its trade networks and abandonment by allies
The expansion of Babylon’s trading empire
The strengthening of Babylon’s political alliances
The rise of Babylon’s merchants to power
questions.correctAnswer: The collapse of its trade networks and abandonment by allies
questions.explanation: This verse predicts the disintegration of Babylon’s economic infrastructure and the desertion by those who once supported it.

questions.question: True or False: In Isaiah 47:4, the 'Holy One of Israel' is contrasted with Babylon’s idolatry, highlighting a central theme of monotheism and divine sovereignty.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:4 identifies the LORD as the Holy One of Israel, contrasting God’s holiness and sovereignty with Babylon’s idolatry, a key thematic element in Isaiah.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 47:9 attributes Babylon’s impending loss and widowhood to the abundance of its sorceries and enchantments, indicating a condemnation of occult practices.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse links Babylon’s downfall to its reliance on sorcery and enchantments, reflecting prophetic critiques of occultism as sinful and ineffective.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 47 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 47 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Isaiah 47:1, what is the depiction of the 'virgin daughter of Babylon' instructed to do?
options: Come down and sit in the dust
questions.correctAnswer: Come down and sit in the dust
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:1 commands the 'virgin daughter of Babylon' to 'Come down, and sit in the dust,' symbolizing humiliation and loss of status. This imagery aligns with themes of divine judgment found in Daniel 4:37 and Revelation 18:7-8 where Babylon’s fall is portrayed as humiliation before God.

questions.question: What task is the daughter of Babylon commanded to do in Isaiah 47:2?
options: Take the millstones and grind meal
questions.correctAnswer: Take the millstones and grind meal
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:2 commands Babylon to 'Take the millstones, and grind meal,' symbolizing forced labor and humiliation. This reflects God's judgment on pride and idolatry as seen in Jeremiah 25:11 and Revelation 18:21 where Babylon's judgment involves grinding and destruction.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 47:4, who is described as the Redeemer?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD of hosts
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:4 identifies 'our redeemer' as 'the LORD of hosts,' affirming God's role as Savior and Holy One of Israel. This echoes the consistent biblical theme of God as Redeemer in Exodus 6:6, Psalm 130:7, Isaiah 43:14, and Hosea 13:4.

questions.question: What is the daughter of the Chaldeans told to do in Isaiah 47:5?
options: Sit silent and get into darkness
questions.correctAnswer: Sit silent and get into darkness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:5 commands the daughter of the Chaldeans to 'Sit thou silent, and get thee into darkness,' signifying judgment and cessation of her former glory. This theme of darkness as judgment is paralleled in Ezekiel 32:7 and Joel 2:2, and Revelation 18:1.

questions.question: Which reason does Isaiah 47:6 give for God's anger against Babylon?
options: Because God was angry with His people and handed them over to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Because God was angry with His people and handed them over to Babylon
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:6 reveals God's anger with His own people and that He 'given them into thine hand,' explaining Babylon’s oppression as a permitted judgment. This aligns with Deuteronomy 32:35 and Romans 9:17 where God uses nations to accomplish His purposes in judgment.

questions.question: What false confidence did Babylon express according to Isaiah 47:7?
options: I shall be a lady forever
questions.correctAnswer: I shall be a lady forever
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:7 records Babylon’s arrogant claim, 'I shall be a lady forever,' reflecting pride and refusal to consider judgment. This prideful confidence is similar to that condemned in Proverbs 16:18 and Luke 1:52, where God opposes the proud.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 47:8, what attitude did Babylon have toward her future judgment?
options: Dwelt carelessly, confident she would not be a widow or lose children
questions.correctAnswer: Dwelt carelessly, confident she would not be a widow or lose children
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:8 describes Babylon as 'given to pleasures' and 'dwelling carelessly,' with a false heart assurance of security. This careless arrogance is comparable to the foolishness condemned in Jeremiah 5:12 and Luke 12:20.

questions.question: What two calamities does Isaiah 47:9 say will come suddenly upon Babylon?
questions.correctAnswer: Loss of children and widowhood
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:9 prophesies that 'loss of children, and widowhood' will come suddenly upon Babylon as judgment for her sorceries and enchantments. This connects with the biblical theme of divine retribution for idolatry in Jeremiah 15:9 and Ezekiel 7:16.

questions.question: What did Babylon trust in according to Isaiah 47:10?
questions.correctAnswer: Her wickedness and wisdom
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:10 states Babylon trusted in 'thy wickedness' and her own 'wisdom and knowledge,' which perverted her. This false trust is condemned in Jeremiah 9:23-24 and Hosea 4:6, emphasizing the folly of trusting in human wisdom instead of God.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 47:11 say will come upon Babylon unexpectedly?
questions.correctAnswer: Evil and mischief
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:11 warns that 'evil' and 'mischief' will come upon Babylon suddenly and unexpectedly, without her understanding. This sudden judgment corresponds with themes in Proverbs 1:27 and 2 Thessalonians 1:7-9 about unexpected divine wrath.

questions.question: What challenge does God present to Babylon in Isaiah 47:12?
options: To stand with her enchantments and sorceries and see if she can profit
questions.correctAnswer: To stand with her enchantments and sorceries and see if she can profit
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:12 challenges Babylon to rely on her magical arts to save herself, highlighting their futility. This mirrors God's repeated condemnation of occult practices in Deuteronomy 18:10-12 and Acts 19:19.

questions.question: Who does Isaiah 47:13 say Babylon should call upon to save her from coming judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: Astrologers, stargazers, and monthly prognosticators
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:13 lists astrologers, stargazers, and prognosticators as those Babylon relies upon for deliverance, emphasizing idolatrous practices. This critique aligns with Isaiah 8:19 and Daniel 2:27-28 which contrast true prophecy with divination.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 47:14, what will happen to the astrologers and sorcerers who try to save Babylon?
options: They will be like stubble burned by fire and unable to save themselves
They will be honored as kings
They will repent and serve God
questions.correctAnswer: They will be like stubble burned by fire and unable to save themselves
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:14 states these enchanters will be like stubble consumed by fire with no ability to save themselves, illustrating the powerlessness of false religions. This is consistent with Malachi 4:1 and Hebrews 10:27 which describe the consuming fire of judgment.

questions.question: What is the fate of Babylon’s merchants as described in Isaiah 47:15?
options: They shall wander every one to his quarter and none shall save Babylon
They will become rulers of nations
questions.correctAnswer: They shall wander every one to his quarter and none shall save Babylon
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:15 depicts Babylon’s merchants as scattered and unable to help her, symbolizing total collapse. This dispersal echoes the scattering of Babylon in Jeremiah 51:13 and Revelation 18:17-19.

questions.question: Which attribute of God is most clearly revealed in Isaiah 47:4?
options: God as Redeemer and Holy One
questions.correctAnswer: God as Redeemer and Holy One
questions.explanation: Isaiah 47:4 declares God as 'our redeemer' and 'Holy One of Israel,' emphasizing His redemptive power and holiness. This is consistent with Exodus 15:13, Psalm 103:1-4, and Isaiah 43:3-4 highlighting God’s saving acts and holiness.
